title: Before 18 July 2020, will President Trump announce that Nikki Haley will be his 2020 running mate?
preds: It does not happen without milking the process for political gains
very unlikely given short timeframe remaining
it is a very specific event within what is now a very small timeframe. don't know anything about this from a political strategy perspective but odds for this specific event seem small.

Pence helped Trump consolidate the evangelical vote in 2016.  That job is done and evangelicals won't leave Trump any under reasonable scenario.  If Trump is behind and feels the need to throw a hail mary, then Nikki Haley is his target in the endzone.   For all his faults, Trump gets strategy, to a fault.  Nikki Haley as VP is a good  strategy in a comeback scenario. If I could get the odds in Vegas, then I would parlay Haley as VP with Pence as Secretary of State in the 2nd term.  Based on the crowd forecasts here, you could probably expect a 1000-1 type of long shot on that type of highly correlated parlay.
No sign or indication of a change.

An older article (https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/03/politics/nikki-haley-mike-pence-trump-vp/index.html), read in our current context, has some counter-reasoning that now seems flimsy. Quote:
Here's why: Trump cares deeply about perception. And projecting an image of utter certainty and strength. A last-minute swap-out of your vice president because you think you can't win without someone new is the exact opposite of that message. It suggests weakness and, even worse, panic.
:End +Long shot before election to get surbuban women (https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/push-donald-trump-older-women-turning-president/story?id=71067257 https://www.startribune.com/suburban-women-a-challenge-for-trump-in-minnesota-battleground/571617482/)
- Pence has been a big part of the COVID-19 response, which is being touted
- Pence has strong evangelical ties
- Pence has been loyal to Trump - Haley is out of the spotlight, Trump would be more interested in someone else
Six months ago, I would have this at 40%. By end of March, over 50%. But now, with such fragile support for Trump, something needs to happen. This isn't it however.

While I think it's highly unlikely, I think Trump is getting increasingly desperate and his behavior more and more erratic, so doing something drastic like this wouldn't surprise me—especially since he doesn't seem to take advice from much of anyone.
Nikki Haley is a great conservative pick for V.P. , but Pence has been a tried and true supporter of the president.  If Pence wants more family time and out of the fray, he may not mind stepping out.
Never. Pence is the perfect lap dog for Trump. He brings so-called Christians into the fold, and does whatever Trump tells him to do. Why get rid of that kind of support?
Haley is smarter than to accept a ticket to the Titanic!
I do not think she would agree to it.
CNN are 100% idiots and probably commies

I still think she has a high degree of likelihood for replacing Pence, but I would suspect Trump would do it in August, on the last day of the dem convention, as phrased by the question.  Less likely to see it happen during the next 2 weeks.
She’s smart. She is on point. She’s loyal. She would make a great VP. Which doesn’t mean she’ll be picked. But she might blunt news cycle re Biden’s pick.
The only thing that makes me consider it a possibility is that as Trump seems to be realizing his chances are in danger, he may throw a hail mary.
She sure is trying hard to back him. If he is going to make a change it would probably be closer to the convention.
Very unlikely but as Trump is falling off a cliff right now, who knows what he might do to break the fall.
Chances of this are decreasing, but still possible something drastic happens in the next 3 weeks.  Lot of uncertainty with COVID.

I'm changing down, again.  But not because I think Trump wouldn't throw Pence aside if he thought it might help.  I DO think he'll do something bold like this, right in the middle or at the end of the Dem convention.  But now I'm thinking Elise Stefanik might be the more likely one than Haley.  He's bringing her along on a lot of events these days.  I fully expect Trump is considering placing all covid blame on Pence.  Trump is hurting badly among suburban women.  He's got the evangelical crowd locked up already, regardless of all evidence that should be to the contrary.

I am increasing my forecast. Once Biden names a female VP, DT might think it would help his Lagging polling numbers if he also had a female on the Ticket. She is the only one on the radar. Plus, DT is big with the blame game and throwing others under the bus.  So his move to put Pence Officially in charge of the pandemic crisis makes him the perfect scapegoat.  Bolton’s new book has some scathing remarks about her, but one of those remarks is her desire to move up the political ladder.  I don’t think anyone sees Pence as a viable candidate in 2024, so there could be party pressure to make the change.  Pence would happily support her, because that is what he does.
Updating, Very unlikely now there will be a change bu t not impossible if poll numbers remain poor and he thinks a change will turn things around.

We now have confirmation that Trump has actively considered swapping Pence for Haley: "Former National Security Adviser John Bolton mercilessly criticizes President Donald Trump in his new book but writes that he had a White House ally in the vice president ... Bolton argued for keeping Pence on the 2020 ticket when Trump asked if he should replace him with Nikki Haley, the former United Nations ambassador." https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/06/21/john-bolton-book-describes-vice-president-mike-pence-alley/3232696001/

You know, I'm going to take a bold stab at this being far more possible than anyone would expect.  Trump has 0% loyalty to anyone when they cease being useful to him.  He could very easily blame Pence for the entire covid response, and I fully expect he will, if he feels it's necessary.  It would certainly shake things up, and make for good tv.  He also likes to distract and get news attention when it's needed, so I think this would actually be a genius move.  Especially when Biden doesn't have the enthusiastic support that he was hoping for, it would suck the wind out of the news cycle for Biden, which would be the point.  She remains oddly loyal to Trump it seems.
Mike Pence will be running mate barring his death or incapacity.
Trump needs to ensure pence’s silence. Trump has not prepared base for pence’s ouster

I think Pence is necessary for his evangelical base and the other good chunk of his base seems to be right wing extremist.  I don’t think he would get away with that for a running mate.  He is losing white, suburban women voters in droves - so there is a chance he would grasp at that Haley straw if it brought them back.  (Doubtful)

Next would he offer her the position. It might help him with suburban women. It would raise her chances of the nomination in 2024 though. Trump would rather elevate one of his children for that role. Ivanka 2024 has already been seen on his bus. Lowering.

Don’t think he has the good sense to do it. I do not see him actually wanting to work with a female. Dump Pence, yes.

With the polls currently not looking good for Trump he may wish to shake things up and steal the thunder from Biden’s announcement of a female running mate at the convention. However Trump being Trump, he won’t want a running mate who outshines him. (Pence could never be accused of that!) Knowing this tempers my prediction a bit.
Trump will stick with Pence barring unforeseen events.

But otherwise unlikely, and no guarantee he'll pick Haley. And I do not buy reports that anybody knows what Trump will do, I think the only certainty is that he's unpredictable.
He will need the boost. And Trump can’t resist such a big splash of a news event.
Would be a good move, but pence has towed trumps line too well to replace.  He can be spur of the moment though so 5-10% in case biden picks a running mate that is moderate conservative before the

Down 10% to be below the consensus. I still believe it likely that DT will dump Pence, but I deluded myself that Haley would be the replacement.

Pompeo is my guess now. This explains the lame brain IG firing before there was an official slap. And why worry about morale or mission if one is headed to greater things? The DT base will be fired up with two aggrieved figureheads. He'd be a better debater, has ties to evangelicals, and obviously the 2.0 would do a much better job managing the next crisis. https://www.politico.com/news/2020/05/16/watchdog-dismissal-mike-pompeo-261871

Let's say the odds that Trump gets rid of Pence sometime before election are 25%. Would seem odd to me if he dumped him after Pence has been in the national spotlight with the coronavirus task force. Even if Trump needs to pick a replacement VP, odds aren't 100% that he'll pick Haley. I'd say 50% or so. So odds of both of the above happening are 13%. But we also have a time constraint. Let's say it's equally likely that all of the above happens between now and the end of the republican national convention at the end of August. That gives all of the above about a 60% chance of happening before July 18. 60% times 13% is approximately 8%.

Given the amount of responsibility that President Trump has given Mike Pence(the Coronavirus Task Force, the National Space Council), and that there are several issues with which Nikki Haley is at odds with Trump's base, it's very unlikely that he will change his plan to make someone who hasn't been introduced to the national public. Mike Pence has been in public consciousness for a long while now, and switching out a team member like that is unlike Trump, as he has tended to reward those who are loyal to him.

A quick check shows since 1988 shows presidential candidates are about 50/50 on whether they announce the VP pick in July vs August.  There are no examples of going back to 1980 of a president picking a diff VP for second term.  So I'm assigning a black box guess of 25% the random chance the Pence is not chosen.   And last for Haley to be picked as a VP over any other potential choice I will also black box at 25%.  So .50 x .25 x .25 = .03125 Last I will add 10% because of the current president's unpredictability decision making track record.

Dropping the estimate due to timing. The original date was set to match the scheduled Democratic convention, but the convention was moved to mid August. At this point I think it as likely than not that Trump will make this switch. I need to think more about electoral college votes. Pence is from Indiana, which is not a swing state, but the evangelicals still love him.  Haley is pro-life, so the evangelicals may be appeased even though she is Sikh by heritage and still attends both Sikh and Methodist services (She identifies as a Christian). She passed the vetting for the UN position relatively easily (96-4).  She is ethnically Punjabi. Not so great for the base perhaps. She is relatively well known, having made a Time 100 most influential people list in 2016.

It's unusual for US president's to switch running mate, and while Trump may choose to jettison Pence (say 50% chance), and may choose to pick a woman to counter Biden's commitment (say conditional probability of 80%), there are a lot of women in this country. Haley is not from a swing state (SC) and that won't help her position. But she is the rumor-mill favorite. What makes this more likely now is that Trump is demonstrably disloyal. He's got Pence setup as COVID guy, which raises Pence's visibility greatly, but also makes him a likely patsy if COVID continues to go bad. It would give Trump an excuse to remove Pence, while distancing himself from the virus disaster, and score identity politics points.  There are only 3 months remaining for him to make this move according to the the terms of the question.

It's unusual for US president's to switch running mate, and while Trump may choose to jettison Pence (say 50% chance), and may choose to pick a woman to counter Biden's commitment (say 70%), there are a lot of women in this country. Haley isn't from a swing state and that will count against her.

While not probable, it is a possibility. Incumbent presidents have chosen a new VP candidate 11 times in U.S. history. While this hasn't happened in approx. 100 years, it would fit Trump's  character to drop his running mate in favor of someone that he thinks may give him an advantage. Especially since Biden says that he will choose a female running mate, Trump could choose one as well to counter Biden.
As the death toll rises and the ineptitude leading to the pandemic and the subsequent federal response gets even more obvious, Pence becomes an easy scapegoat.

Pence is too tightly bound to Christian conservatives, and Trumps political fate is too tightly bound to them.

If he were to remove himself (under pressure) then Nikki Haley is the most likely choice and a balance to the democratic ticket..
The time period is not long enough to give it a higher score.
Down 30% now that the D convention has moved to August. Timing would be better closer to the (virtual?) conventions.
I think it is unlikely Trump tries to change anything big because of the coronavirus.

In the modern presidential era, no candidate has ever switched their VP. So we begin with 99-1. However, Trump is unconventional and by placing Pence in charge of the COVID-19 response he may be setting up a scenario where he blames Pence and switches him out for Nikki Haley. However this scenario has low probability and strikes me as a hail mary if the COVID-19 response goes poorly.

If things go wrong probably will see vice-president Pence in prime time trying to cotain the debacle and eventually discarded for mistakes. Mike Pence is doing fine. No reason for trump to dump him.
I believe she'd rather run for the top job in 2024.
since first forecast, the pandemic as changed the political landscape and now is not the time to go long on changes

Although I do see where Begala is coming from, I just don't see this happening. The reason that I am giving a percentage here as high as 10% is simply because of Trump's showmanship- he is known to love a good plot twist, and theoretically it could be a smart political move to try and sway middle-ground women in favor of the Republican ticket now should it include a woman as Vice President. This may be even more probable since Begala made his claim on March 2, as Joe Biden, the presumptive Democratic nominee, promised to name a woman as his running mate in a debate with Bernie Sanders on March 15, so Trump could use this as a tactic to match Biden and block him from using the "female VP" card to his advantage. However, despite all this, it still seems highly improbable that this will actually happen. For one, current VP Mike Pence is a very "stable" candidate, contrary to Trump's colorful personality that many traditional GOP members dislike, and who has already proven himself capable of the position. Additionally, a change in running mate when running for reelection has only been done three times in U.S. history, and the most recent instance was when President Franklin D. Roosevelt ran for an unprecedented third term with a new running mate in 1940. Many Americans, Democrat and Republican alike, agree that Pence has been a very capable leader in his position at the head of the COVID-19 response task force, and he has a strong favorability rating among most Republicans, making him a reliable partner. Even if Trump does decide to dump Pence, there is no guarantee that he would replace him with Haley, or even if Haley would accept the position. This seems like an idea that might sound okay on paper, but in all likelihood will not work out in practice, if it is even attempted at all. https://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2013/11/vice-presidential-swaps-throughout-history
https://www.cnn.com/videos/politics/2020/03/19/donald-trumps-2020-vice-president-mike-pence-nikki-haley-cillizza-the-point.cnn

It seems doubtful, especially given the Covid-19 outbreak, that Trump would announce a new running mate at this time. The focus of the administration and its reelection concerns at the moment  is far more focused on ensuring that the economy does not enter a long term recession or face a financial meltdown. Additionally, it will be unclear how the administration will need to increase its support amongst voters until after the Democratic national Convention, anticipated to be in July. The Covid=19 pandemic will likely push this back past. the July 18th timeframe.      This being said, I do believe that Trump will likely drop Pence as his running mate in favor of Nikki Haley. Trump needs to gain the support of middle class, moderate, suburban women voters in order to win reelection in a variety of states. Pence was a strategic running mate in 2016 as he signaled to the evangelical christian voting bloc that it would not be selling out its values by voting for Trump. Now that Trump has (however moderately) advocated for policies that the evangelical community supports, it appears unlikely that the many evangelicals will switch (especially the case if Bernie Sanders, a secular jew, were the democratic candidate). A moderate female republican will signal to moderate suburban female voters that Trump is at least palatable, in a similar way that Pence signaled such to the evangelical community.      Since the DNC is scheduled for 7/13-7/16, if the Covid-19 outbreak mitigates quicker than expected  and a decision on the democratic candidate is made during that time frame, the administration may announce its intention to run with Haley immediately in order to draw media attention toward a new story, accounting for my 10% "yes" opinion.
Paul Begala who said it was "a certainty," just wanted attention and overstated his confidence. Pence will be very hard to get rid of after the competent job he does with the coronavirus response.
Following the economic collapse, with Pence in charge of "fixing" coronavirus, POTUS will use the opportunity to make this change.  It will be an attempt to offset Biden having a female VP
It's not impossible -- that's the best I can say for it.
He has no need to change with Pence
Revising down from previous forecast on chance Haley says no for her own reasons. My reasoning otherwise still stands. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/994339

The coronavirus right now is taking its toll on the economy and over time will take a toll on Trump's popularity, despite the recent slight bump up.  Trump asking Nikki Haley to run is very likely.  However, I really doubt Nikki Haley will want to be associated with Trump during this period.  It could ruin her chances of running for president or senator in the future.  Also, vice presidents of failed presidential nominees, even incumbents, historically do not do well afterward.   Therefore, I think Trump will probably ask at some point, but I doubt she will accept.   There are other fish in the sea who could help with the woman or black vote, but none nearly as popular as Haley. I am cutting my estimate in half.   Oh, and for Pence, Trump will throw him under the bus without giving it a second thought no matter how much Pence tries to portray himself as a loyal number two.
Pence to be tested, not making Haley more likely, but making the prospect more relevant: https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/488808-pence-says-he-will-be-tested-for-coronavirus
Not sure it’s the right person.  But we have to see if Trump gets sick first.  Virus will delay most things.  Also if Pence does good job with pandemic then it would be hard to drop him.
Nikky Haley resigning from the Boeing board indicates her independence.
Upgrading slightly due to putting Pence in charge of coronavirus response (which will turn bad).

Trump has confirmed Pence as his VP already for 2020. Begala's argument that Haley would draw votes from "suburban moms" means little, considering the sheer number of white women ages 25-40 Trump/Pence drew during the 2016 election. There is little to be gained from a switch in VP this late in the game, especially considering how soon Trump's 2020 campaign began--the day of his inauguration in 2017.  Logistically, it's enough work that no one would advise it. However, this does not rule out the likelihood of Trump making a spur of the moment decision, which is why I am not going for an absolute zero here. Anything is possible. Unfortunately.

I think President Trump will name Niiki Haley as his VP pick on two conditions: 
1. if coronavirus response is not going well (lack of public confidence) then President Trump will fault VP Pence and choose a new running mate and 2. If Biden has chosen a female running mate

Highly unlikely. While Pence is far less important to the ticket in '20 than he was in '16 (reassuring social and evangelical conservatives that they can vote for a New Yorker with a history of liberal social issue stances, who spent considerable time in his life as a Democrat), Trump and Pence now have fairly similar favorability numbers and approvals. It wouldn't make much of a difference as voters don't vote based on the bottom of the ticket for the most part. The GOP also might want to avoid the association of their next nominee (another prediction) with Trump and see Haley is a viable bridge candidate between the new GOP or the Trump GOP and the old GOP. Far more likely is the odds Nikki Haley runs in 2024 (95%), wins the nomination (40%, plurality leader in a crowded field), and becomes the first female U.S. President (65% in a one-on-one matchup, but overall: .95 x .4 x.65).
if this is happening, doubt it's own this timeline due to corona.
Nikki Haley looks good, and the femaler/ethicity thing works for her. But there are lots of other possibilities
She's the best choice, but Trump might feel that he wants to stick with Pence, who is a loyal yes man.
Trump needs the evangelical base that Pence represents. Evangelicals will never accept a woman President.

It is very unlikely for Trump to change his VP, especially to a woman.
1.  Biden will have a female running mate.  Trump will not allow himself to follow Biden's lead in choosing a woman.
2.  There is no need for Trump to pick a woman running mate - unlike Biden, his constituents do not demand it.
3.  If offer, Haley is likely to decline.  The common view is that Trump will lose in the next election.  There is no reason for her to join a losing team - how many losing VP candidates can you remember?  She is likely to go into a presidential run, but she can wait after the election.
Trump will be advised to wait until he has no choice but to announce his running mate. If he decides to go with Haley, he will wait until what he thinks is the ideal moment.

Outside view/Base rate: 
Incumbent presidents who switched VPs when running for second term: 5 [1,2] 
- 1864: Lincoln switching from Hamlin to Johnson
- 1872: Grant switching from Colfax to Wilson
- 1892: Harrison switching from Morton to Reid
- 1944: Roosevelt switching from Wallace to Truman
- 1976: Ford switching from Rockefeller to Dole
* Not counting VP Garner challenging Roosevelt in 1940, forcing Roosevelt to choose Wallace as a new running mate. Or Agnew resigning under Nixon, causing Nixon to pick a new running mate. Or VPs dying during first term, causing president to pick new running mate. 
* Also starting since Civil War given "historically, presidential nominees had little role in choosing who their running mate was. Party leaders made the choice, with ticket-balancing usually the chief concern. As a result, presidents and vice presidents frequently had little to do with one another, with vice presidents frequently accorded no role at all in the administration." [3] Incumbents seeking second term and VP didn't die in first term: 13 (Lincoln, Grant, Harrison, Wilson, FDR x2, Eisenhower, Nixon, Carter, Reagan, Clinton, Bush, Obama) [1,2]  That would put base rate at 5/13 = 38% (honestly way higher than I expected before answering this question) Inside view: 
- Begala (analyst who made the claim) is probably just trying to grab headlines with a bold claim, so should not be taken as a prediction made for accuracy
- However, Begala's argument is two-fold: 1) Trump would announce to interrupt the DNC's selection of their nominee, which is plausible. 2) Trump would throw Pence under the bus for mismanagement of coronavirus response, which also seems plausible. [4] 
- Pence appears to have similar favorability ratings to Trump, but better net ratings (lower unfavorability), so I'm not sure it would make sense for Trump to drop Pence because of Pence's favorability [5,6,7]
- It could make sense for Trump to bring in Haley to compete with Biden's female VP, which he promised in the latest debate with Sanders. 
- Trump thinks highly of Haley and she has favorable ratings [8]
- Trump has high turnover in existing cabinet, so could make sense to replace VP
- Assuming equal distribution of probability between now and the Republican convention 8/23, 77% chance that Trump would announce between now and Democratic convention 7/18. 
- Haley has denied rumors of being the replacement
- Crowd: 6% Inside view: 10% Forecast: 25% [1] https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1810034
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_presidential_election#Electoral_college_results
[3] https://www.quora.com/If-a-President-is-elected-for-a-second-term-can-they-choose-a-different-Vice-President
[4] https://thehill.com/homenews/media/485562-cnns-begala-trump-will-dump-pence-for-haley-on-day-of-democratic-nominees
[5] https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/other/pence_favorableunfavorable-6013.html
[6] https://www.bustle.com/p/mike-pences-2019-approval-rating-shows-how-many-people-have-apparently-never-heard-of-him-15924448
[7] https://news.gallup.com/poll/243725/opinion-pence-remains-divided.aspx
[8] https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/10/9/17955654/nikki-haley-resign-news

From 1944 - 2012, of the 12 Presidents who have run for reelection, only 2 have changed Vice Presidents (VP) during reelection (1944 Wallace -> Truman, 1976 Rockefeller -> Dole) - 16.7% = 2/12 * 100%. Take into account the turnover (Total 10) in Trump's Cabinet from 2017 - 2019 compared to Reagan - Obama (Average 3.4), Vice President Pence is a member of the Cabinet - 49% = 16.7% * (10/3.4) Likelihood of President Trump deciding to replace Vice President Pence = 49% 3 factors that reportedly led to Pence being chosen Vice President in 2016 were -
1 - Was a State Governor & former Congressman, knew Washington DC allowing Trump to put him to be in charge of US "domestic & foreign affairs" 
2 - Strong links to Republican Voters (Especially Christian Conservative) & Donors which Trump needed in 2016 to prove his Republican credentials given he had never been a Republican before 
3 - He was a Yes Man who wouldn't challenge Trump. In this forecast will assume that the decision to Keep/Remove Pence will be made solely in relation to the 2020 US Presidential Election in increasing Trump's chances for re-election. Keep Pence -
1 - Changing VP could be seen as a sign of weakness, lose face with voters & donors.
2 - Is needed in motivating & energizing base, his connections with certain voters & donors aren't replaceable.
3 - Is a loyalist which Trump reportedly values above all and doesn't challenge him.
4 - Pence has important roles & positions in the Administration and allies in Republican Party & Administration that will successfully resist his removal. Remove Pence -
1 - Since 2017 Trump has established his Republican credentials with Republican voters (e.g., typical 90% approval rating) & donors (e.g. Sheldon Adelson), Pence is no longer needed to provide this.
2 - Unlike in 2016 when Trump faced Hillary Clinton, an unpopular candidate, he will likely face Joe Biden, a popular candidate while Trump has remained divisive & unpopular. Selecting a new, popular Vice President who reaches swing suburb voters who changed from 2016 to vote Democrat in 2018 midterms (Pence I believe doesn't reach them) could increase Trump re-election chances. In other words Trump would energize his rural base with the new VP attracting moderate, swing suburb voters by "ticket balancing" leaving Democrats only urban voters in 2020 election. 
3 - That with the Trump takeover of the Republican Party, Pence isn't needed as perhaps was in 2016 in soothing Republican Establishment fears & worries about Trump and if he wants to he can get rid of Pence. On reflecting on all these reasons to Keep/Remove Pence, I am won over by the reasons to Remove Pence if there exists a replacement who I believe would be chosen if are -
1 - Popular & attracts suburb voters and Trump base.
2 - Is a Trump loyalist.
3 - Is a current / former Governor (helps if from a swing state, Pence is from Indiana which is always Republican so isn't an advantage).
4 - Has Republican Establishment links to soothe concerns on Pence removal. Assuming the decision to replace Pence is made, does Trump choose to replace him with Nikki Haley or Someone Else ? Possible replacements are -
1 - Nikki Haley (4/4) - Former Governor of South Carolina (won twice), High Favourables, Trump reportedly really likes her, chosen by Republican Party to give State of the Union Address response in 2016.
2 - Rick Scott (3/4) - would have to give up Florida Senate Seat which was extremely close in 2018. Suspect Republicans want to keep control of Senate second to winning Presidency.
3 - Scott Walker (2/4) As a woman, 48 year old to Trump's 73 years old, non-white, popular, Trump loyalist Republican, I do believe that Nikki Haley would bring greater electoral advantage for Trump as VP than either Rick Scott or Scott Walker in addressing his unfavourability ratings in the suburbs. Therefore give probability of Trump wanting Haley as new VP = 90%, Someone Else = 10%. Likelihood that Trump will want to remove Pence and ask Haley to be his new Vice President -
 44% = 49% * 0.9 If asked would Nikki Haley say Yes to being Vice President? I would personally say unlikely e.g. 20%. The Vice Presidency is a potential jumping point for the Presidency in 2024, but on the other-hand she very likely will not want to be directly associated with the Trump Campaign / White House as a VP to avoid future scandals & chaos which may hurt a future presidential bid in 2024. 
Reportedly many people are declining prestigious positions such as Defence Secretary and White House Chief of Staff as do not want to be directly connected / involved with Trump. I found this Atlantic & Vox article to be very insightful as to her possible VP thinking - 
https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2019/11/disavowing-trump-isnt-part-nikki-haleys-long-game/601987/
https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/10/9/17955654/nikki-haley-resign-news Likelihood of Haley saying Yes to being Vice President -
9% = 0.2 * 48% If Haley says yes, will it be announced before 18/7/2020 ? The Democratic National Convention is 13 - 16/7/2020, Republican National Convention is 24 - 27/8/2020. Declaring Haley as the new VP during the DNC it reminds me of the before a 2016 Debate where Trump & Bannon organized a conference with Bill Clinton's accusers. By announcing it during the DNC it would take away news coverage away from Democrats with Trump known as a skilled media manipulator/showman. Today's date is 11/3/2020. Its 129 days from 17/7/2020 and 166 days from 23/8/2020 (appears that Vice President nominees are announced before that Party's convention). Likelihood before 18/7/2020 the announcement that Haley will be Trump's 2020 running mate -
 7% = 129/166 * 9% While a very intriguing idea, and certainly makes a lot of sense from the Trump's campaigns perspective, I do believe that Nikki Halley is entirely focused on the 2024 Presidential Election and wants to spend the next 4 years planning & organizing her Presidential campaign and stay away from the partisanship in Washington -
https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/campaigns/latest-nikki-haley-fundraising-event-sure-to-fuel-2024-speculation
Trump has been known to throw his closest allies under the bus at his convenience but I think Pence is still popular among evangelicals.

I am upping my forecast for two reasons. First, the coronavirus is going badly for Trump and will continue going badly for Trump.  He will need a fall guy and that is Mike Pence.  Haley solves several problems at the same time,  such as minority woman on ticket and she is politically skilled and talented.
It depends on how well Pence handles the Corona virus situation. He has to walk a fine line between not stepping on Trump's messages while giving the public factual and useful information.

Trump is doing very poorly with one significant Republican demographic: suburban college educated women.   He is losing this traditional constituency by about 2 to 1.   I suspect Trump  realizes this could cost him the election.   To that end, I understand per a David Plouffe MSNBC interview that it is an awfully lot easier to get back a constituency than acquire a new one.    Nikki Haley was popular with both parties when she left the UN.  (See poll below.)  She is sort of the Republican's Michelle Obama. Therefore, Haley could help Trump a lot in regaining the Republican woman's vote and capture some Democrat votes.   She is also a woman of color who might bring back a few Republican leaning Latinos and Asians. Pence adds little to the Trump ticket.  In fact, I suspect they appeal to exactly the same Republican voters so I doubt there is not one swing voter in America who will switch from Biden (the most likely Democratic nominee) to Trump because Pence is on the ticket.  Of course, loyalty is very important to Trump.  He demands it.  But it is a one way street.  He will fire his most loyal staff members  the instant he concludes they are no longer useful to him or it was otherwise in his interest.  The examples are too many to mention, and if the reader cannot think of one, there is probably no hope for that reader.  The probability of Trump asking Haley to join the ticket rises as Trump's popularity declines during the coronavirus pandemic and resulting economy decline.  The only reason I can think of for Trump not to ask Haley to join the ticket Haley would become the most likely presidential nominee for 2020.  I suspect Trump wants one of his children, almost certainly Ivanka, to succeed him.  However, that is a possible problem down the road; Trump has a real problem right now.   But why would Nikki Haley accept such an offer?  VP nominees tend to disappear rather quickly from the political spotlight when the ticket loses.  No one remembers the running mates after a few years.  Gore's VP candidate, Joe Lieberman even lost the Democratic nomination for his own senate seat in 2006, which he had held for 18 years.   Sarah Palin was a flash in the public spotlight for a little while, but she too disappeared.    On the other hand, a lot of Vice presidents are elected-- or reelected-- president, e.g., George H. W. Bush, Richard Nixon, Lyndon Johnson, Harry Truman (and even Al Gore won the popular vote.)   Yet, Haley is currently popular across the political spectrum while Trump is easily the most polarizing president in my lifetime--and probably in history.  All presidents are somewhat polarizing, but Trump is different.  There are a number of former Republicans pulling for Biden because they hate Trump so much.  This did not happen in large numbers with any other president, even Nixon.   Some commentators claim the only reason Trump has a >90 percent approval rating with his base is because so many Republicans have left the party.  (I did not verify this but it rings at least somewhat true.) Hence, I am not sure Nikki Haley would get the boost in a future presidential election, e.g., 2024, that other vice presidents received.  Haley might see her chances of becoming president diminish by accepting such a nomination.  As Trump's star fades so does the probability of Nikki Haley accepting any such offer.    Yet, I understand the white house-itis is very contagious to any one in reach, and Trump as president and dictator of the Republican party could offer to help her in other ways, e.g., all but guarantee her the 2024 presidential nomination.  (But, if she is smart, she will know he will not keep such a promise.) The mid-July deadline is an issue. The Republican National Convention is set for August 24 - August 27.  Therefore, Haley must accept such an offer no later than the last day of the convention.  Replacing a party nominated VP Pence  would be much more difficult at that point, if even possible.  The primaries end on June 7.  The Democratic convention runs from July 13 to 16.   I think Trump would make the announcement at the end of  the primaries at the earliest.  Therefore, any announcement would occur between June 7 and August 27.  Trump might want to wait until after July 16 to see who the democrats nominated, or  Trump might want to make the announcement during the democratic convention to take the spotlight away.   I think there would be a benefit to announcing earlier because it would create a "bounce" in the polls, and the early announcement might give the pro-Haley enthusiasm a chance "to set" with the voters. 

Therefore, 85 percent chance of Trump asking or desiring Haley to replace Pence. (He might not ask if he is sure she will not accept.)   Nikki has a 60 percent chance of accepting.  However, the deadline of over a month prior to the convention so a 75 percent chance of making the appointment during this period.  (.85 x .6 x .75= 38 percent) Yet, I don't know why but my gut feeling is that this is much more likely to happen than 38 percent.  Of course, if Haley refuses an offer, It will not be made public until after the election. https://poll.qu.edu/national/release-detail?ReleaseID=2538

Nicki Haley will not be selected as a running mate because of her previous conversion to Christianity, her history of being accused of affairs, her tea party association, and her 2024 presidential aspirations. I have provided more analysis below.  First, she has a controversial history with the religious right after her conversion from Sikhism prior to running for Governor of SC. This could raise unnecessary questions amongst Trump's base, especially if she is selected over a white, evangelical, male who has no controversies. Second, she has been accused of having multiple affairs in the past (not making a comment on the veracity/truthfulness of those accusations) which is something the current administration continues to deal with and is unlikely to want to deal with again. Third, she was a member of the tea party movement and would have to defend the spending by the current administration while explaining why she changed her fiscally conservative views. Finally, she seems to have presidential aspirations for 2024 and history has shown that sitting VP's do not do well when they run for President after 8 years of the same party being in charge. 14 VP's have become President in the nation's history with only 1 (Bush) being elected to the office immediately following their tenure as VP since 1836 (Tyler, Fillmore, A Johnson, Arthur, Roosevelt, Coolidge, Truman, L Johnson, and Ford all became President after the previous President either died or resigned). Nixon is an outlier as he was Eisenhower's VP and lost in the 1960 election, but won in 1968 and 1972.

- Unlikely to change VP historically.
- Even if VP is changed, there would only be a very small chance to pick Nikki Haley.
- 1% due to Trump's unpredictability + his perception of Pence's handling of coronavirus.

Only one president in the modern era has had multiple VPs, that being FDR. The odds of Trump ditching Pence therefore seem small, Trump also recently entrusted the coronavirus response to Pence, and event which if mishandled could reflect very poorly on the president. Trump is an unconventional politician however and there is a chance (probably <10%) that he would chose to move on from Pence. Nikki Haley seems like a strange replacement however, many have theorized that Trump originally picked Pence to appeal to Republican party elites Nikki Haley would be in the same vein so it seems odd to dump Pence for her. If Trump was to replace Pence it would likely be with someone he is personally close with, as that is how he has filled out much of his staff.

Two staged question, he has to get rid of Pence, then select and get Haley. On the first question, people have already considered the base rate so no need for me to go over that again.  Haley would be the second female VP candidate, if she were to accept. She refused to be Trumps VP in 2016, but this was at the time when republicans probably thought Trump would lose. If it looks like Trumps position isn't certain before the 18th July, you can easily see why Haley will not want to be his VP again. She has already resigned once from his cabinet, but they left on good terms.
It looks like a rumor at this point. Plus Trump said replacing Pence would be a great act of disloyalty. Plus he seems to like Pence because he's a pushover. Why replace him?

The Current Incumbent has announced his unflagging love for Pence.  On past form, this is the kiss of death.   Pence helped to haul in self-styled "Christians" in '16, so his work is finished here, while Haley is believed to appeal to a different demographic.  However, if  Biden is the D candidate, M. Petits-Doigts will pick up no new female or minority voters this year; and at least some actual Christians seem to be catching on and so won't vote for the Current Incumbent even if Pence is still on the ticket.  But if he dumps Pence, he might lose still more churchgoers.   The main thing going against Haley is that she is obviously seventeen times smarter than The Leader Of The Free World.  He is terrified of women who are obviously smarter than he is (a tremendous  proportion of the female population of the world) and the VP is just about the only member of the Administration the Prez can't fire.   She would be well advised to refuse the offer if it's made, spend the summer making half-hearted speeches of lukewarm support in venues that don't get much national press, and wait for lightning to strike in '24.  If she spends the '22 off-years giving rousing speeches for R candidates in largish markets, she can emerge as The Big Kahuna in '24 without being further tainted by association. Most likely the Prince of Orange will decide to bear those ills he has than fly to others that he knows not of.  Still, anything can happen.  I am sort of comfortable at 24% but am probably wrong.

It is unlikely as Trump likes a Vice President who just keeps his mouth shut but in recent weeks Pence has made some statements on Covid19 test kits that has ruffled Trump.  Who knows if Pence's heading up Covid19 was a poisoned chalice given to him by Trump.  If he cocks up... Trump may dump him.

Trump has shown he has no issue replacing members of his staff quite abruptly. Additionally, this could be a way to counter a female on the Biden or Sanders ticket. The responses to questions regarding the possibility have not been firm.
Trump will need to offset a Democrat's announcement of a woman VP (Klobuchar??) and Haley would be a good pick if Trump is not intimidated by her potential. Can you have an "acting" VP?

It is very likely that the democratic candidate will have a woman as the Vice-presidential candidate. As a counter move, Trump may also have a woman as his running mate. Nikki Haley checks many boxes to get considered as the running mate.

I can see President Trump trying to attract attention away from the Democrats, and picking a woman would spite one of their attack lines (while not actually resolving it - it plays into a particular conception on the part of the right as far as bigotry goes).
That said, there's no saying that he'd ditch Pence (ditching your VP isn't common and, while I'd need to do more research to check, I don't know of any feud between the two), or that Nikki Haley would be the pick if he did. I'm definitely not inclined to take the word of a contributor looking to go viral with a wacky prediction that will be forgotten about (except by a subset of the people answering this question) by the time it comes to testing it. And, actually, it's CNN so that counts against the reliability of this. I'm certainly no fan of the President who thusly hates that particular network: I just think Trump would try to defy any prediction from them.

Since turn of 20th century only one president switched from their initial vp choice. This is a little over 7%. Trump is unconventional and has been known to fire cabinet members with some frequency so I added 2%. I cut that by 2/3 for much the same reason.
Trump will try to control the narrative.. shift the discussion.. away from something else..

45 presidents, but 5 chose not to run, so 40 presidents running for re-election.  9 of them had different vice presidents, putting a base rate at 22.5% (9/40). Gave a slight bump based on current presidential behavior and a 2018 article saying she was a front runner.  Would give a higher bump, but media also predicted Clinton would replace Biden on Obama's  reelection ticket.  https://www.rollcall.com/2018/11/26/seven-vp-candidates-if-trump-dumps-pence-for-2020-re-election-fight/
https://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2013/11/vice-presidential-swaps-throughout-history

Since 1900 only one incumbent president has changed their VP (that picked their VP the first time), FDR who did it twice picking Truman in 1944 and Wallace in 1940. All other presidents kept their VP, which total 12 elections between 1900 and 2012. This gives a base rate of 2/14 = 14%. I'd suggest that more recent observations are more pertinent and so a more reasonable base rate is around 5-10%.  Broadly, Trump seems relatively content with Pence. In addition, Pence does appear to be a stabilizing force for the white house, and throwing him out may cost votes in important battle grounds states. Similarly, Pence has been in the white house the past 4 years, thus kicking him out may be costly if he decides to retaliate. I think it's highly unlikely Trump drops Pence at all. I'd say there is a 5% chance he changes VP.  It's harder to know who Trump will pick if he drops Pence. Haley seems like the most probable candidate - she's friends with Ivanka, Trump gave her a role in his administration previously, and she was floated as a possibility in 2016. However, there are plenty of other candidates out there as well. Even if I give her a 60% chance of being the VP conditional on changing from Pence, that leaves me with a final prediction of 3-5%. I'll go with that for now.
